meaning: The four symbols used in chemical equations to represent state of matter: (aq), (s), (l) and (g).
A solution in which the solvent is water.
A mixture of two or more metals
Refers to electrons in metallic bonding leaving their shells in order to freely move around.
A substance containing particles that are free to move around to carry thermal or electrical energy.
Strong forces between oppositely charged ions.
A type of bond where a non metal and a metal form oppositely charged ions, attracted to each other by electrostatic forces.
A structure formed by ionic bonding where all particles form ionic bonds with their neighbouring particles, arranged in a chequerboard pattern.
A type of bond between non-metals, where they share one or more electrons.
The weak forces in between simple covalent molecules.
A giant structure where atoms are joined to adjacent atoms with covalent bonds.
A giant covalent structure made of carbon where each atom forms 4 covalent bonds with adjacent carbon atoms.
A giant covalent structure made of carbon where each atom forms 3 covalent bonds with adjacent atoms. Divided into layers, which are attracted to each other by intermolecular forces.
A giant covalent structure made of carbon where each atom forms 3 covalent bonds with adjacent atoms - only one layer, with a hexagonal pattern.
A nanoparticle made from carbon atoms, with a hollow shape
Incredibly small particles with diameters between 1 and 100 nanometres.
